content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is introduced under Part B of title III of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, providing awards for schools to promote innovation in technology. The purpose of the "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is to expand knowledge about advanced technology in education, address national questions about technology's impact on teaching, and develop innovative technology models for widespread adoption in education. The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" authorizes the Secretary to award grants for innovative technology projects aligned with academic standards, using various devices and software. Grants are awarded competitively for up to 5 years through the Office of Educational Technology. "SEC. 3212. ELIGIBILITY." To be eligible for an award under this part, a consortium must include a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education, for-profit entity, museum, library, or other entity with relevant expertise. The application must describe the project and include a plan for independent evaluation. The Secretary may require an application for project funding to include a description of the proposed project, a detailed plan for independent evaluation, and priorities for innovative use of educational technology and large-scale technology innovations across multiple states. Priority for projects may include serving multiple states, large-scale technology innovations, innovative models for underserved populations, substantial financial resources, challenging courses through electronic networks, and high-speed technology establishment. Priority for projects includes developing innovative models for challenging courses through electronic networks, such as Advanced Placement courses, and establishing high-speed, large bandwidth capacity Internet access. "SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS." "A recipient must use funds awarded under this part to develop new educational technology applications, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out other activities consistent with the purposes of this part, such as improving teachers' ability to integrate technology into course curriculum." The recipient must use funds to develop innovative models for improving teachers' ability to integrate technology into curriculum and create high-quality digital content, including multimedia software and simulation tools. The curr_chunk discusses various innovative technologies for education, including computer modeling, simulation tools, new assessment methods, web-based learning curricula, digital libraries, and software for educational material development. The curr_chunk discusses using telecommunications and technology to make educational programs accessible to students with special needs, providing opportunities for female students to explore technology, careers, and opportunities in the technology field. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting school-family partnerships, acquiring connectivity resources, and collaborating with other technology research for educational programs. The curr_chunk involves collaborating with technology research programs and the Federal government to support distance learning networks and services for educational projects. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct independent evaluations, and disseminate findings to promote effective models for evaluating the impact of educational technology. The recipient of funds under this part is limited to using no more than 3 percent of the funds for administrative costs or technical assistance. The Secretary may require recipients of funds to share in the cost of activities assisted, not exceeding 50% of the total cost. The non-Federal share required will be published in the Federal Register. "Authorization of appropriations for activities assisted by the Secretary may require recipients to share up to 50% of the total cost." "For fiscal year 2001 and the following four years, necessary sums are authorized to be appropriated. Repeal of former program for National Challenge Grants includes amendments to specific sections of the Act." For fiscal year 2001 and the following four years, necessary sums are authorized to be appropriated. Repeal of former program for National Challenge Grants includes redesignating subsections and headings in the Act.
